Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Part trap, part torture device, part magic removal mechanism, the weave stripper is a gold-banded, lead-lined box that houses a portal to a remote, antimagical corner of the Abyss. The denizens of this void feed on the Weave, forcibly removing it from the creatures around which it is woven.

Pandora's Box. As an action while holding this box, you can place it down and unlock it, causing it to slowly and eerily creep open. Each creature that starts its turn in the area or moves into it for the first time on its turn must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. If the creature is under the effect of a spell or concentrating on one, it has disadvantage on the saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes [[/r 4d8]] psychic damage, it loses concentration if it is concentrating on a spell, and any magical effect or spell of 5th level or lower that is affecting it is dispelled. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and no additional effects occur.

As an action, a creature within reach of the box can attempt a DC 15 Strength check, closing it on a success. Otherwise, after 1 minute, these abyssal creatures satiate themselves, retreat back into the box, the effect ends, and the box can be closed normally. Once this property of the item has been used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

Part trap, part torture device, part magic removal mechanism, the weave stripper is a gold-banded, lead-lined box that houses a portal to a remote, antimagical corner of the Abyss. The denizens of this void feed on the Weave, forcibly removing it from the creatures around which it is woven.

Pandora's Box. As an action while holding this box, you can place it down and unlock it, causing it to slowly and eerily creep open. At the end of your turn, black mist spews forth in a 20-foot radius sphere centred on the box, soon followed by writhing, ethereal purple tentacles that flail and thrash wildly.

Each creature that starts its turn in the area or moves into it for the first time on its turn must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw. If the creature is under the effect of a spell or concentrating on one, it has disadvantage on the saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes [[/r 3d6]] psychic damage, it loses concentration if it is concentrating on a spell, and any magical effect or spell of 3rd level or lower that is affecting it is dispelled. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and no additional effects occur.

As an action, a creature within reach of the box can attempt a DC 13 Strength check, closing it on a success. Martial weapon, melee weapon 2 lb.
[[/r 1d8]] piercing - finesse

The faces of trapped souls can be seen floating beneath the polished surface of this deep, inky glass weapon. The secrets of fashioning soulveil, the faceted material from which these weapons are made, predate even the Spellbreakers. Before wielding such a weapon against a magic user, they must have first been tried by a Spellbreaker Council and found guilty of the most dire crimes. Death by this weapon is absolute, a final curtain.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Soultrap. This weapon can store a maximum of 20 charges. When you use this weapon to kill a creature capable of casting spells, the creature's soul is trapped in the weapon, which gains a number of charges equal to half the creature's total number of Hit Dice. As these charges are expended, the creature's soul is shredded. A creature whose soul is trapped or shredded can't come back to life by any means short of a @Compendium[dnd5e.spells.qLeEXZDbW5y4bmLY]{True Resurrection} spell or similar magic.

Empower. When you hit a target with an attack using this weapon, you can expend up to 5 charges, dealing an extra [[/r 1d8]] force damage for each charge expended.

Finesse. When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

Magehunter Blade Greatsword (Very Rare).name: Magehunter Blade Greatsword (Very Rare)
Magehunter Blade Greatsword (Very Rare).description:
Weapon, very rare (requires attunement)
Martial weapon, melee weapon 6 lb.
[[/r 2d6]] slashing - heavy, two-handed

Made of a Weave-intersecting alloy, these armaments were the go-to weapon for the mage-hunting Order of the Spellbreakers. Fanatical elements within the order have recently taken power, bringing with them an abhorrence for all things arcane. Having largely destroyed their magical arsenal, such weapons have become quite rare and are only wielded by the few who cling to the old ways.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Dispel Magic. When you hit a target that is under the effect of one or more spells with an attack using this weapon, you can choose to dispel one of the spells affecting it if the spell is of 5th level or lower. If you do, the target takes [[/r 1d6]] force damage for each level of the spell (dispelled cantrips deal no extra damage). Once a spell is dispelled, roll a [[/r d6]]. If the number is equal to or lower than the level of the dispelled spell, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Heavy. Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

Two-Handed. This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

Speak No Evil (Uncommon).name: Speak No Evil (Uncommon)
Speak No Evil (Uncommon).description:
Wondrous item, uncommon

This headgear-a gag consisting of two leaden 'hands' connected by thick leather straps-is designed to make speech impossible.

Applying the Gag. As an action, you can attempt to gag a creature you are grappling. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. On a success, you get the gag in place and the leather straps magically fasten.

The Gagged. The gagged creature can't verbalise in any way, which includes speaking, casting spells that require a verbal component, or even simply humming and grunting.

In addition, after the creature casts a spell, the gag heats up and the creature takes [[/r 1d4]] fire damage plus an extra [[/r 1d4]] fire damage per level of the spell.

Removing the Gag. You and any creature you designate when you use the gag can use an action to remove it. The gagged creature or a creature within reach of it can use its action to make a DC 20 Strength or DC 15 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check, removing the gag on a success. The knock spell can also unfasten the leather straps, causing the gag to fall off.
